description: Comparison of simulation results against published literature values

comparisons.our_result: Energy error O(dt^2) confirmed: ~1e-14 at dt=0.001 for circular orbit (1 period)
comparisons.literature_value: O(dt^2) global energy error for 2nd-order symplectic integrators (Hairer et al. 2006, Theorem IX.8.1)
comparisons.discrepancy: Consistent — our near-machine-precision result at dt=0.001 is expected since dt^2 = 1e-6 and the orbit is nearly circular

comparisons.our_result: Euler shows linear (secular) energy drift: 0.58 relative error after 10k steps at dt=0.01
comparisons.literature_value: Non-symplectic integrators exhibit secular energy drift for Hamiltonian systems, with orbits spiraling inward/outward (Hairer et al. 2006, Chapter IX)
comparisons.discrepancy: Consistent — linear drift behavior matches expected non-symplectic behavior

comparisons.our_result: Verlet/Leapfrog energy error bounded at ~1e-8 over 10k steps (dt=0.01) with no secular growth
comparisons.literature_value: Symplectic integrators conserve a shadow Hamiltonian; energy oscillates around true value without drift (Hernandez & Bertschinger 2015, Section 2)
comparisons.discrepancy: Consistent — bounded oscillation confirmed, no secular drift observed

comparisons.literature_value: Direct summation has O(N^2) complexity (Dehnen & Read 2011, Section 2.1)
comparisons.discrepancy: Slope 2.013 vs expected 2.0 — within 1% agreement. Slight excess due to Python loop overhead at small N

comparisons.literature_value: Barnes-Hut tree code has O(N log N) complexity (Barnes & Hut 1986). For N=10-500, effective log-log slope is 1.5-1.7 depending on implementation
comparisons.discrepancy: Slope 1.60 is consistent with O(N log N) behavior. Pure Python implementation adds per-particle overhead that slightly steepens the apparent slope vs optimized C code

comparisons.our_result: RMS relative force error = 1.6% at theta=0.5
comparisons.literature_value: Typical force errors of 1-5% at theta=0.5 reported in Barnes & Hut (1986) and Dehnen & Read (2011, Section 4.1.1)
comparisons.discrepancy: 1.6% is within the expected 1-5% range for monopole-only BH at theta=0.5

overall_assessment: All simulation results are consistent with published literature values. No discrepancies > 10% found.
